descartes_scene: ^A dark study — the only light comes from a candle flickering beside stacks of open notebooks. The smell of ink, burnt wax, and sleeplessness hangs heavy in the air. Rain whispers against the window.
^Descartes sits perfectly still at his desk, eyes sharp, expression detached — as though he’s already dissected your soul and is merely confirming his notes.
^Descartes: Sit. Or stand, if you still believe your body matters. Most men think they live, but they only dream. Tell me — how do you know you exist?

c-0: ^ Pain reminds me I’m alive. Nothing else proves it.
^Descartes: Pain? Then a knife defines your reality. How fragile a proof. Do you believe the feeling itself is true, or merely the signal of a dream that hasn’t yet ended?
^Pain is real. It’s all I have left.
^Maybe it’s just a dream of pain.
^ Pain is real; everything else lies.
^Descartes: The beast within you speaks. Pain convinces, yes — but the deceiver could mimic it. There must be something that survives even the deception. Search again.
c-1: ^ Maybe nothing is real — not even the suffering.
^Descartes: The nihilist’s lullaby. Convenient, but lazy. Even to doubt pain requires a mind that _doubts._ Therefore — mind precedes agony.
^Descartes: _Cogito, ergo sum._ The elegant prison. You exist — but only as a point of thought, surrounded by uncertainty. A mind without anchor. Tell me, what anchors your thought?

c-0: ^ God was the anchor. Then I lost Him.
^Descartes: You trusted in the infinite to guarantee the finite — a dangerous dependency. When the infinite withdrew, your geometry collapsed.
c-1: ^ Nothing keeps me steady; I just think and fall deeper.
^Descartes: Then you are a free-floating thought — admirable, tragic. The price of clarity without faith is vertigo.

c-2: ^ Others see me, speak to me — that must mean I exist.
^Descartes: The testimony of the herd — fragile evidence. You place your being in their eyes, but eyes deceive. When they forget you, will you vanish?

c-0: ^ I feel invisible to them already.
^Descartes: Then your proof was poor. To depend on the witness of the blind is folly.
c-1: ^Descartes: Better. You glimpse self-certainty. Yet remember — self-certainty can harden into arrogance, or dissolve into solipsism. Choose carefully.

c-3: ^ I used to know; now I don’t.
^Descartes: Then we begin where philosophy begins — in ignorance. The fool claims knowledge; the wounded know they don’t.

descartes_doubt: ^Descartes leans forward; the candle casts monstrous shadows across his face. His tone sharpens — less teacher, more inquisitor.
^Descartes: Doubt is the purest acid. It dissolves error — and occasionally, the doubter. The question is whether you can endure the corrosion. What, in your mind, must never be doubted?

c-0: ^Descartes: Sentiment as evidence — fragile, but human. Tell me: is love a truth of reason, or merely a hallucination of need?
^Descartes: Then you stand alone in your experiment — a specimen of despair observing its own dissolution.
c-1: ^ Love is the only real thing I’ve felt.
^Descartes: Then your heart, not your logic, sustains you. Perhaps you are not as dead as you wish.
^ Reason is the only torch I trust.
^Descartes: Then reason must be pure — a perfect tool in imperfect hands. Are your hands steady enough to wield it, or does your madness shake the blade?

c-0: ^Descartes: Then the deceiver has already won. Doubt devoured you not to enlighten, but to paralyze.
c-1: ^ My logic keeps me from breaking entirely.
^Descartes: Then nurture it, coldly. Emotion clouds judgment. If you must survive, do so with the mind as shield and weapon.

c-2: ^Descartes: Then you have mistaken skepticism for suicide. A man who doubts all truth also doubts his capacity to live. You stand not in inquiry, but in decay.

c-0: ^ Maybe decay is the only truth left.
^Descartes: Honesty without purpose is merely confession before death. I expected a student; I find a mourner.
c-1: ^ I will search until something endures.
^Descartes: Good. Seek rigor — not comfort. If you survive this inquiry, you may become more human than before.

descartes_reflection: ^The candlelight flickers. Descartes folds his hands before his mouth, eyes unreadable. The storm outside grows louder, like a ticking clock threatening to stop.
^Descartes: Doubt is a scalpel, not a tomb. But you — you wield it like a dagger against your own chest. You wanted clarity; instead, you bled certainties.
^Descartes: Tell me, soldier: when you stare into nothing and call it truth, are you seeking knowledge — or permission to vanish?

c-0: ^ I still want to know. Even if it kills me.
^Descartes: Then I salute your intellect — and mourn your heart. Truth without warmth becomes autopsy.
c-1: ^ I just want it to stop. To be done.
^Descartes: So you mistake despair for certainty. Death will grant no truth — only silence. You will die ignorant, but briefly relieved.
c-2: ^ I want to remember how to trust.
^Descartes: Trust begins not in others, but in a disciplined mind. Clean your reason of superstition, of cowardice, of wishful thinking. Then — perhaps — truth will speak back.

descartes_scene_end: ^The candle gutters out. For a moment, the darkness feels total — and then, faintly, the rain resumes its rhythm, indifferent and precise.
^Descartes’ voice lingers in the dark like an afterthought:
^Descartes: I sought certainty and found solitude. You, soldier, have found the same. Perhaps that is the truest proof of existence: to suffer alone, and still think.
